question: What are the names of authors whose institutions are in the US?
sub_query: List of authors with institutions in the US
document_path: https://zhujuneray.github.io/assets/provenance/data/paper/raw_data/When Personal Tracking Becomes Social: Examining the Use of Instagram for Healthy Eating.pdf
final_answer: To identify the names of authors whose institutions are in the US, we can refer to the provided sub-answers. The authors affiliated with institutions in the US are Eric PS Baumer, Phil Adams, and Geri K Gay. Additionally, institutions in the US that funded the study include the National Science Foundation, the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, the University of Washington, and Microsoft. These institutions provided funding for the study conducted by the aforementioned authors.
sub_answers: Eric PS Baumer is affiliated with the United States. Phil Adams is affiliated with the United States. Geri K Gay is affiliated with the United States.

Institutions in the US that funded the study include the National Science Foundation, the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, the University of Washington, and Microsoft. The study was conducted in part with funding from these institutions.

23. Andrea Grimes, Martin Bednar, Jay D Bolter, and

METHODS 
We conducted semi-structured interviews with 16 participants 
who self-identify as using Instagram to support their healthy 
eating and/or fitness goals. We recruited participants through 
a pre-screening survey shared via researcher social networks, 
direct  messages  to  Instagram  users  who  use  specific  food 
tracking  hashtags  (#fooddiary  and  #foodjournal)  and  use 
English in their posts, and snowball sampling via interview 
participants.  Each  interview  participant  was  compensated 
with a $10 gift card. Participants were primarily located in 
the US, with two from the UK (I09 and I11, Table1).

food photos to a local community server with explicit goals 
to  help  community  members  improve  their  healthy  diet 
practice. These photos were later shared anonymously in a 
public  kiosk  where  other  community  members  could  rate 
whether the photo was inspirational [44]. By thinking about 
how  to  provide  helpful  food  photos,  users  reflect  on  their 
own food choices and preparation processes.
